texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> The row permission and column masks for the CUSTOMERS table are based on the group of which the user profile is part. If the user is a customer, their specific login ID also is tested.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> The row permission and column mask for the ACCOUNTS table are based on the CUSTOMERS table permission rules. A subquery is used to connect the accounts (child) with the customer (parent).
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> The row permission and column mask for the ACCOUNTS table are based on the CUSTOMERS table permission rules. A subquery is used to connect the accounts (child) with the customer (parent).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> The row permission for the TRANSACTIONS table is based on the ACCOUNTS table permission rules and the CUSTOMERS table permission rules. A subquery is used to connect the transactions (child) with the account (parent) and the account (child) with the customer (parent).
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> The row permission for the TRANSACTIONS table is based on the ACCOUNTS table permission rules and the CUSTOMERS table permission rules. A subquery is used to connect the transactions (child) with the account (parent) and the account (child) with the customer (parent).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: RCAC and non-SQL interfaces
texts.text: RCAC and non-SQL interfaces

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A benefit of Row and Column Access Control (RCAC) is that its security controls are enforced across all the interfaces that access DB2 for i because the security rules are defined and enforced at the database level. The examples that are shown in this paper focus on SQL-based access, but row permissions and column masks also are enforced for non-SQL interfaces, such as native record-level access in RPG and COBOL programs and CL commands, such as Display Physical File Member ( DSPPFM ) and Copy File ( CPYF ).
texts.text: A benefit of Row and Column Access Control (RCAC) is that its security controls are enforced across all the interfaces that access DB2 for i because the security rules are defined and enforced at the database level. The examples that are shown in this paper focus on SQL-based access, but row permissions and column masks also are enforced for non-SQL interfaces, such as native record-level access in RPG and COBOL programs and CL commands, such as Display Physical File Member ( DSPPFM ) and Copy File ( CPYF ).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This consistent enforcement across all interfaces is a good thing, but there are some nuances and restrictions as a result of applying an SQL-based technology such as RCAC to non-SQL interfaces. These considerations are described in this chapter.
texts.text: This consistent enforcement across all interfaces is a good thing, but there are some nuances and restrictions as a result of applying an SQL-based technology such as RCAC to non-SQL interfaces. These considerations are described in this chapter.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The following topics are covered in this chapter in this chapter:
texts.text: The following topics are covered in this chapter in this chapter:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.1 Unsupported interfaces
texts.text: 5.1 Unsupported interfaces

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It is not possible to create a row permission or column mask on a distributed table or a program-described file.
texts.text: It is not possible to create a row permission or column mask on a distributed table or a program-described file.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: After a row permission or column mask is added to a table, there are some data access requests that no longer work. An attempt to open or query a table with activated RCAC controls involving any of the following scenarios is rejected with the CPD43A4 error message:
texts.text: After a row permission or column mask is added to a table, there are some data access requests that no longer work. An attempt to open or query a table with activated RCAC controls involving any of the following scenarios is rejected with the CPD43A4 error message:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> A logical file with multiple formats if the open attempt requests more than one format.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> A logical file with multiple formats if the open attempt requests more than one format.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> A table or query that specifies an ICU 2.6.1 sort sequence.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> A table or query that specifies an ICU 2.6.1 sort sequence.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> A table with read triggers.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> A table with read triggers.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This unsupported interface error occurs when a table with RCAC controls is accessed, not when the RCAC control is created and activated.
texts.text: This unsupported interface error occurs when a table with RCAC controls is accessed, not when the RCAC control is created and activated.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For example, assume that there is a physical file, PF1, which is referenced by a single format logical file (LFS) and a multi-format logical file (LFM). A row permission is successfully created and activated for PF1. Any application that accesses PF1 directly or LFS continues to work without any issues. However, any application that opens LFM with multiple formats receives an error on the open attempt after the row permission is activated for PF1.
texts.text: For example, assume that there is a physical file, PF1, which is referenced by a single format logical file (LFS) and a multi-format logical file (LFM). A row permission is successfully created and activated for PF1. Any application that accesses PF1 directly or LFS continues to work without any issues. However, any application that opens LFM with multiple formats receives an error on the open attempt after the row permission is activated for PF1.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important: This potential runtime error places a heavy emphasis on a comprehensive testing plan to ensure that all programs are tested. If testing uncovers an unsupported interface, then you must investigate whether the application can be rewritten to use a data access interface that is supported by RCAC.
texts.text: Important: This potential runtime error places a heavy emphasis on a comprehensive testing plan to ensure that all programs are tested. If testing uncovers an unsupported interface, then you must investigate whether the application can be rewritten to use a data access interface that is supported by RCAC.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.2 Native query result differences
texts.text: 5.2 Native query result differences

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The SQL Query Engine (SQE) is the only engine that is enhanced by IBM to enforce RCAC controls on query requests. In order for native query requests to work with RCAC, these native query requests are now processed by SQE instead of the Classic Query Engine (CQE). Native query requests can consist of the following items:
texts.text: The SQL Query Engine (SQE) is the only engine that is enhanced by IBM to enforce RCAC controls on query requests. In order for native query requests to work with RCAC, these native query requests are now processed by SQE instead of the Classic Query Engine (CQE). Native query requests can consist of the following items:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Query/400
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Query/400

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> QQQQRY API
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> QQQQRY API

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Open Query File ( OPNQRYF ) command
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Open Query File ( OPNQRYF ) command

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Run Query ( RUNQRY ) command
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Run Query ( RUNQRY ) command

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Native open (RPG, COBOL, OPNDBF, and so on) of an SQL view
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Native open (RPG, COBOL, OPNDBF, and so on) of an SQL view

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Legacy queries that have been running without any issues for many years and over many IBM i releases are now processed by a different query engine. As a result, the runtime behavior and results that are returned can be different for native query requests with RCAC enabled. The OPNQRYF command and Query/400 run with SQE by default.
texts.text: Legacy queries that have been running without any issues for many years and over many IBM i releases are now processed by a different query engine. As a result, the runtime behavior and results that are returned can be different for native query requests with RCAC enabled. The OPNQRYF command and Query/400 run with SQE by default.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The following list documents some of the query output differences that can occur when native query requests are processed by CQE:
texts.text: The following list documents some of the query output differences that can occur when native query requests are processed by CQE:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Different ordering in the result set
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Different ordering in the result set

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Different values for null columns or columns with errors
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Different values for null columns or columns with errors

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Suppression of some mapping error messages
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Suppression of some mapping error messages

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Loss of RRN positioning capabilities
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Loss of RRN positioning capabilities

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Duplicate key processing behavior differences
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Duplicate key processing behavior differences

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Missing key feedback
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Missing key feedback

texts.text: For a list of the differences and additional details, see the IBM i Memo to Users Version 7.2 , found at:

texts.text: http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/ssw_ibm_i_72/rzahg/rzahgmtu.htm

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In addition, the performance of a native query with SQE can be different. It is possible that a new index or keyed logical file might need to be created to improve the performance.
texts.text: In addition, the performance of a native query with SQE can be different. It is possible that a new index or keyed logical file might need to be created to improve the performance.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important: Based on the potential impacts of query result set and performance differences, you should perform extensive functional testing and performance benchmarking of applications and reports that use native query interfaces.
texts.text: Important: Based on the potential impacts of query result set and performance differences, you should perform extensive functional testing and performance benchmarking of applications and reports that use native query interfaces.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.3 Accidental updates with masked values
texts.text: 5.3 Accidental updates with masked values

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The masked values that are returned by a column mask can potentially cause the original data value to be accidentally overwritten, especially with applications using native record-level access.
texts.text: The masked values that are returned by a column mask can potentially cause the original data value to be accidentally overwritten, especially with applications using native record-level access.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For example, consider a table containing three columns of first name, last name, and tax ID that is read by an RPG program. The user running the program is not authorized to see the tax ID value, so a masked value (*****3333) is written into the program's record buffer, as shown Figure 5-1.
texts.text: For example, consider a table containing three columns of first name, last name, and tax ID that is read by an RPG program. The user running the program is not authorized to see the tax ID value, so a masked value (*****3333) is written into the program's record buffer, as shown Figure 5-1.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In this example, the application reads the data for an update to correct the misspelling of the last name. The last name value is changed to Smith in the buffer. Now, a WRITE request is issued by the program, which uses the contents of the record buffer to update the row in the underlying DB2 table. Unfortunately, the record buffer still contains a masked value for the tax ID, so the tax ID value in the table is accidentally set to the masked value.
texts.text: In this example, the application reads the data for an update to correct the misspelling of the last name. The last name value is changed to Smith in the buffer. Now, a WRITE request is issued by the program, which uses the contents of the record buffer to update the row in the underlying DB2 table. Unfortunately, the record buffer still contains a masked value for the tax ID, so the tax ID value in the table is accidentally set to the masked value.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 5-1 Accidental update with masked values scenario
texts.text: Figure 5-1 Accidental update with masked values scenario

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Obviously, careful planning and testing should be exercised to avoid accidental updates with masked values.
texts.text: Obviously, careful planning and testing should be exercised to avoid accidental updates with masked values.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: DB2 for i also enhanced its check constraint support in the IBM i 7.2 release with a new ON UPDATE clause that allows the existing value to be preserved when a masked value is detected by a check constraint. Details about how to employ this new check constraint support can be found in 6.8.1, "Check constraint solution" on page 108.
texts.text: DB2 for i also enhanced its check constraint support in the IBM i 7.2 release with a new ON UPDATE clause that allows the existing value to be preserved when a masked value is detected by a check constraint. Details about how to employ this new check constraint support can be found in 6.8.1, "Check constraint solution" on page 108.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.4 System CL commands considerations
texts.text: 5.4 System CL commands considerations

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As stated earlier, RCAC controls are enforced on all data access interfaces. This enforcement is not limited to programmatic interfaces; it also includes system CL commands that read and insert data, such as the Create Duplicate Object ( CRTDUPOBJ ) and Start DFU ( STRDFU ) CL commands. This section documents the behavior of the Create Duplicate Object ( CRTDUPOBJ ), Copy File ( CPYF ), and Copy Library ( CPYLIB ) CL commands with RCAC.
texts.text: As stated earlier, RCAC controls are enforced on all data access interfaces. This enforcement is not limited to programmatic interfaces; it also includes system CL commands that read and insert data, such as the Create Duplicate Object ( CRTDUPOBJ ) and Start DFU ( STRDFU ) CL commands. This section documents the behavior of the Create Duplicate Object ( CRTDUPOBJ ), Copy File ( CPYF ), and Copy Library ( CPYLIB ) CL commands with RCAC.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.4.1 Create Duplicate Object (CRTDUPOBJ) command
texts.text: 5.4.1 Create Duplicate Object (CRTDUPOBJ) command

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The CRTDUPOBJ command is enhanced with a new Access Control ( ACCCTL ) parameter in the IBM i 7.2 release to copy RCAC controls to the new object being created. Row permissions and column masks are copied to the new object by default because the default value for the ACCCTL parameter is *ALL .
texts.text: The CRTDUPOBJ command is enhanced with a new Access Control ( ACCCTL ) parameter in the IBM i 7.2 release to copy RCAC controls to the new object being created. Row permissions and column masks are copied to the new object by default because the default value for the ACCCTL parameter is *ALL .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the invoker of the CRTDUPOBJ command asks for data to be copied with a value of *YES for the DATA parameter, the value of the ACCCTL parameter must be *ALL . If not, the command invocation receives an error.
texts.text: If the invoker of the CRTDUPOBJ command asks for data to be copied with a value of *YES for the DATA parameter, the value of the ACCCTL parameter must be *ALL . If not, the command invocation receives an error.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When data is copied to the duplicated object with the DATA parameter, all rows and unmasked column values are copied into the new object, even if the command invoker is not authorized to view all rows or certain column values. This behavior occurs because the RCAC controls also are copied to the new object. The copied RCAC controls enforce that only authorized users are allowed to view row and column values in the newly duplicated object.
texts.text: When data is copied to the duplicated object with the DATA parameter, all rows and unmasked column values are copied into the new object, even if the command invoker is not authorized to view all rows or certain column values. This behavior occurs because the RCAC controls also are copied to the new object. The copied RCAC controls enforce that only authorized users are allowed to view row and column values in the newly duplicated object.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.4.2 Copy File (CPYF) command
texts.text: 5.4.2 Copy File (CPYF) command

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The CPYF command copies only data, so there is no new parameter to copy RCAC controls to the target table. Therefore, if CPYF is used to create a target table, there are no RCAC controls placed on the target table.
texts.text: The CPYF command copies only data, so there is no new parameter to copy RCAC controls to the target table. Therefore, if CPYF is used to create a target table, there are no RCAC controls placed on the target table.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When RCAC controls are in place on the source table, the CPYF command is limited to reading rows and column values that are based on the invoker of the CPYF command. If a user is authorized to see all rows and column values, then all rows and unmasked column values are copied to the target table (assuming no RCAC controls are on the target table). If a user without full access runs the CPYF command, the CPYF command can copy only a subset of the rows into the target table. In addition, if that user can view only masked column values, then masked values are copied into the target table. This also applies to the Copy to Import File ( CPYTOIMPF ) command.
texts.text: When RCAC controls are in place on the source table, the CPYF command is limited to reading rows and column values that are based on the invoker of the CPYF command. If a user is authorized to see all rows and column values, then all rows and unmasked column values are copied to the target table (assuming no RCAC controls are on the target table). If a user without full access runs the CPYF command, the CPYF command can copy only a subset of the rows into the target table. In addition, if that user can view only masked column values, then masked values are copied into the target table. This also applies to the Copy to Import File ( CPYTOIMPF ) command.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the target table has RCAC controls defined and activated, then the CPYF command is allowed only to add or replace rows in the target table based on the RCAC controls. If CPYF tries to add a row to the target table that the command invoker is not allowed to view according to the target RCAC controls, then an error is received.
texts.text: If the target table has RCAC controls defined and activated, then the CPYF command is allowed only to add or replace rows in the target table based on the RCAC controls. If CPYF tries to add a row to the target table that the command invoker is not allowed to view according to the target RCAC controls, then an error is received.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5.4.3 Copy Library (CPYLIB) command
texts.text: 5.4.3 Copy Library (CPYLIB) command

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The CPYLIB command is enhanced with the same Access Control ( ACCCTL ) parameter as the CRTDUPOBJ command in the IBM i 7.2 release (see 5.4.1, "Create Duplicate Object (CRTDUPOBJ) command" on page 82). Row permissions and column masks are copied to the new object in the new library by default because the default value for the ACCCTL parameter is *ALL .
texts.text: The CPYLIB command is enhanced with the same Access Control ( ACCCTL ) parameter as the CRTDUPOBJ command in the IBM i 7.2 release (see 5.4.1, "Create Duplicate Object (CRTDUPOBJ) command" on page 82). Row permissions and column masks are copied to the new object in the new library by default because the default value for the ACCCTL parameter is *ALL .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.1 Timing of column masking
texts.text: 6.1 Timing of column masking

texts.label: text
texts.orig: An important design and implementation consideration is the fact that RCAC column masking occurs after all of the query processing is complete, which means that the query results are not at all based on the masked values. Any local selection, joining, grouping, or ordering operations are based on the unmasked column values. Only the final result set is the target of the masking.
texts.text: An important design and implementation consideration is the fact that RCAC column masking occurs after all of the query processing is complete, which means that the query results are not at all based on the masked values. Any local selection, joining, grouping, or ordering operations are based on the unmasked column values. Only the final result set is the target of the masking.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: An example of this situation is shown in Figure 6-1. However, note that aggregate functions (a form of grouping) are based on masked values.
texts.text: An example of this situation is shown in Figure 6-1. However, note that aggregate functions (a form of grouping) are based on masked values.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Conversely, field procedure masking causes the column values to be changed (that is, masked) and stored in the row. When the table is queried and the masked columns are referenced, the masked data is used for any local selection, joining, grouping, or ordering operations. This situation can have a profound effect on the query's final result set and not just on the column values that are returned. Field procedure masking occurs when the column values are read from disk before any query processing. RCAC masking occurs when the column values are returned to the application after query processing. This difference in behavior is shown in Figure 6-2.
texts.text: Conversely, field procedure masking causes the column values to be changed (that is, masked) and stored in the row. When the table is queried and the masked columns are referenced, the masked data is used for any local selection, joining, grouping, or ordering operations. This situation can have a profound effect on the query's final result set and not just on the column values that are returned. Field procedure masking occurs when the column values are read from disk before any query processing. RCAC masking occurs when the column values are returned to the application after query processing. This difference in behavior is shown in Figure 6-2.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Note: Column masks can influence an SQL INSERT or UPDATE . For example, you cannot insert or update a table with column access control activated with masked data generated from an expression within the same statement that is based on a column with a column mask.
texts.text: Note: Column masks can influence an SQL INSERT or UPDATE . For example, you cannot insert or update a table with column access control activated with masked data generated from an expression within the same statement that is based on a column with a column mask.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.2 RCAC effects on data movement
texts.text: 6.2 RCAC effects on data movement

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As described earlier and shown in Figure 6-3, RCAC is applied pervasively regardless of the data access programming interface, SQL statement, or IBM i command. The effects of RCAC on data movement scenarios can be profound and possibly problematic. It is important to understand these effects and make the appropriate adjustments to avoid incorrect results or data loss.
texts.text: As described earlier and shown in Figure 6-3, RCAC is applied pervasively regardless of the data access programming interface, SQL statement, or IBM i command. The effects of RCAC on data movement scenarios can be profound and possibly problematic. It is important to understand these effects and make the appropriate adjustments to avoid incorrect results or data loss.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-3 RCAC and data movement
texts.text: Figure 6-3 RCAC and data movement

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The "user" that is running the data movement application or process, whether it be a high availability (HA) scenario, an extract, transform, load (ETL) scenario, or just copying data from one file or table to another one, must have permission to all the source rows without masking, and not be restricted from putting rows into the target. Allowing the data movement application or process to bypass the RCAC rules must be based on a clear and concise understanding of the organization's object security and data access policy. Proper design, implementation, and testing are critical success factors when applying RCAC.
texts.text: The "user" that is running the data movement application or process, whether it be a high availability (HA) scenario, an extract, transform, load (ETL) scenario, or just copying data from one file or table to another one, must have permission to all the source rows without masking, and not be restricted from putting rows into the target. Allowing the data movement application or process to bypass the RCAC rules must be based on a clear and concise understanding of the organization's object security and data access policy. Proper design, implementation, and testing are critical success factors when applying RCAC.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important: RCAC is applied to the table or physical file access. It is not applied to the journal receiver access. Any and all database transactions are represented in the journal regardless of RCAC row permissions and column masks. This makes it essential that IBM i security is used to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to the journaled data.
texts.text: Important: RCAC is applied to the table or physical file access. It is not applied to the journal receiver access. Any and all database transactions are represented in the journal regardless of RCAC row permissions and column masks. This makes it essential that IBM i security is used to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to the journaled data.

texts.orig: For example, given a "source" table with a row permission defined as NAME <> 'CAIN' and a column mask that is defined to project the value 999.99 for AMOUNT, the SELECT statement produces a result set that has the RCAC rules applied. This reduced and modified result set is inserted into the "target" table even though the query is defined as returning all rows and all columns. Instead of seven rows that are selected from the source, only three rows are returned and placed into the target, as shown in Figure 6-4.

texts.text: Given a "source" table and a "target" table with a row permission defined as NAME <> 'CAIN' and a column mask that is defined to project the value 999.99 for AMOUNT, the SELECT statement produces a result set that has the RCAC rules applied. This reduced and modified result set is inserted into the "target" table even though the query is defined as returning all rows and all columns. Instead of seven rows that are selected from the source, only three rows are returned.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Although the source rows where NAME <> 'CAIN' do satisfy the target table's permission, the AMOUNT column value of 999.99 represents masked data and therefore cannot be inserted. An error is returned indicating the failure, as shown in Figure 6-6. In this scenario, DB2 is protecting against an overt attempt to insert masked data.

An error is returned indicating the failure, as shown in Figure 6-6. In this scenario, DB2 is protecting against an overt attempt to insert masked data.

texts.orig: 6.3 RCAC effects on joins
texts.text: 6.3 RCAC effects on joins

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As mentioned previously, a fundamental concept of row permission is that it defines a logical subset of rows that a user or group of users is permitted to access and use. This subset becomes the new basis of any query against the table that has RCAC enabled.
texts.text: As mentioned previously, a fundamental concept of row permission is that it defines a logical subset of rows that a user or group of users is permitted to access and use. This subset becomes the new basis of any query against the table that has RCAC enabled.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Note: Thinking of the row permission as defining a virtual set of rows that can be operated on is the secret to understanding the effect of RCAC on any join operation.
texts.text: Note: Thinking of the row permission as defining a virtual set of rows that can be operated on is the secret to understanding the effect of RCAC on any join operation.

texts.orig: As shown in Figure 6-7, there are two different sets, set A and set B. However, set B has a row permission that subsets the rows that a user can see.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.3.1 Inner joins
texts.text: 6.3.1 Inner joins

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Inner join defines the intersection of two data sets. For a row to be returned from the inner join query, it must appear in both sets, as shown in Figure 6-8.
texts.text: Inner join defines the intersection of two data sets. For a row to be returned from the inner join query, it must appear in both sets, as shown in Figure 6-8.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-8 Inner join without RCAC permission
texts.text: Figure 6-8 Inner join without RCAC permission

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Given that row permission serves to eliminate logically rows from one or more sets, the result set from an inner join (and a subquery) can be different when RCAC is applied. RCAC can reduce the number of rows that are permitted to be accessed by the join, as shown in Figure 6-9.
texts.text: Given that row permission serves to eliminate logically rows from one or more sets, the result set from an inner join (and a subquery) can be different when RCAC is applied. RCAC can reduce the number of rows that are permitted to be accessed by the join, as shown in Figure 6-9.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Effect of column masks on inner joins: Because column masks are applied after the query final results are determined, the masked value has no effect on the join processing and corresponding query result set.
texts.text: Effect of column masks on inner joins: Because column masks are applied after the query final results are determined, the masked value has no effect on the join processing and corresponding query result set.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-9 Inner join with RCAC permission
texts.text: Figure 6-9 Inner join with RCAC permission

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.3.2 Outer joins
texts.text: 6.3.2 Outer joins

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Outer joins preserve one or both sides of two data sets. A row can be returned from the outer join query if it appears in the primary set (LEFT, RIGHT, or both in the case of FULL), as shown in Figure 6-10. Column values from the secondary set are returned if the row has a match in the primary set. Otherwise, NULL is returned for the column value by default.
texts.text: Outer joins preserve one or both sides of two data sets. A row can be returned from the outer join query if it appears in the primary set (LEFT, RIGHT, or both in the case of FULL), as shown in Figure 6-10. Column values from the secondary set are returned if the row has a match in the primary set. Otherwise, NULL is returned for the column value by default.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-10 Outer join without RCAC permission
texts.text: Figure 6-10 Outer join without RCAC permission

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Given that row permission serves to eliminate logically rows from one or more sets, more column values that are returned from the secondary table in outer join can be NULL when RCAC is applied, as shown in Figure 6-11.
texts.text: Given that row permission serves to eliminate logically rows from one or more sets, more column values that are returned from the secondary table in outer join can be NULL when RCAC is applied, as shown in Figure 6-11.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Effect of column masks on inner joins: Because column masks are applied after the query final results are determined, the masked value has no effect on the join processing and corresponding query result set.
texts.text: Effect of column masks on inner joins: Because column masks are applied after the query final results are determined, the masked value has no effect on the join processing and corresponding query result set.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.3.3 Exception joins
texts.text: 6.3.3 Exception joins

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Exception joins preserve one side of two data sets. A row can be returned from the exception join query if it appears in the primary set (LEFT or RIGHT) and the row does not appear in the secondary set, as shown in Figure 6-12. Column values from the secondary set are returned as NULL by default.
texts.text: Exception joins preserve one side of two data sets. A row can be returned from the exception join query if it appears in the primary set (LEFT or RIGHT) and the row does not appear in the secondary set, as shown in Figure 6-12. Column values from the secondary set are returned as NULL by default.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-12 Exception join without RCAC permission
texts.text: Figure 6-12 Exception join without RCAC permission

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Given that row permission serves to eliminate logically rows from one or more sets, more rows can appear to be exceptions when RCAC is applied, as shown in Figure 6-13. Also, because column masks are applied after the query final results are determined, the masked value has no effect on the join processing and corresponding query result set.
texts.text: Given that row permission serves to eliminate logically rows from one or more sets, more rows can appear to be exceptions when RCAC is applied, as shown in Figure 6-13. Also, because column masks are applied after the query final results are determined, the masked value has no effect on the join processing and corresponding query result set.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-13 Exception join with RCAC permission
texts.text: Figure 6-13 Exception join with RCAC permission

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.4 Monitoring, analyzing, and debugging with RCAC
texts.text: 6.4 Monitoring, analyzing, and debugging with RCAC

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It is assumed (and it is a critical success factor) that the database engineer or application developer has a thorough understanding of the DB2 for i Query Optimizer, Database Engine, and all the associated tools and techniques.
texts.text: It is assumed (and it is a critical success factor) that the database engineer or application developer has a thorough understanding of the DB2 for i Query Optimizer, Database Engine, and all the associated tools and techniques.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The monitoring, analyzing, and debugging process basically stays the same when RCAC row permissions or column masks are in place, with a few important differences:
texts.text: The monitoring, analyzing, and debugging process basically stays the same when RCAC row permissions or column masks are in place, with a few important differences:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> The underlying data access plan can be different and more complex based on the rule text.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> The underlying data access plan can be different and more complex based on the rule text.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> The database results can be reduced or modified based on the rule text and user profile.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> The database results can be reduced or modified based on the rule text and user profile.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> The run time of the request can be affected either positively or negatively based on the rule text.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> The run time of the request can be affected either positively or negatively based on the rule text.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> For high-level language record level access, query plans must be considered, and not just program code.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> For high-level language record level access, query plans must be considered, and not just program code.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: During analyzing and debugging, it is important to account for all of the RCAC definitions for each table or file to understand the logic and corresponding work that is associated with processing the row permissions and column masks. It is also important to realize that, depending on the user profile in effect at run time, the database actions and query results can be different.
texts.text: During analyzing and debugging, it is important to account for all of the RCAC definitions for each table or file to understand the logic and corresponding work that is associated with processing the row permissions and column masks. It is also important to realize that, depending on the user profile in effect at run time, the database actions and query results can be different.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: RCAC is designed and implemented to be transparent to the user. It is possible for user "Mike" and user "Hernando" to run the exact same query, against the exact same data on the exact same system, and get different result sets. There is no error, no warning, and no indication that RCAC reduced or modified the respective answers that are returned. Furthermore, it is also likely that user "Mike" and user "Hernando" have different query run times even though it appears that everything is the same for both users. The actual query plan contains the RCAC logic, and this additional code path can alter the amount of work that is needed to produce results, based on the user running the query.
texts.text: RCAC is designed and implemented to be transparent to the user. It is possible for user "Mike" and user "Hernando" to run the exact same query, against the exact same data on the exact same system, and get different result sets. There is no error, no warning, and no indication that RCAC reduced or modified the respective answers that are returned. Furthermore, it is also likely that user "Mike" and user "Hernando" have different query run times even though it appears that everything is the same for both users. The actual query plan contains the RCAC logic, and this additional code path can alter the amount of work that is needed to produce results, based on the user running the query.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When monitoring, analyzing, and debugging a database process when RCAC is enabled, it is critical to keep as many of the "variables" the same as possible. Use a good scientific process. For example, when re-creating a problem situation running under the same user profile with the same data and under the same conditions, it is almost mandatory. Otherwise, the database behavior and query results can be different.
texts.text: When monitoring, analyzing, and debugging a database process when RCAC is enabled, it is critical to keep as many of the "variables" the same as possible. Use a good scientific process. For example, when re-creating a problem situation running under the same user profile with the same data and under the same conditions, it is almost mandatory. Otherwise, the database behavior and query results can be different.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: To successfully perform monitoring, analyzing, and debugging when RCAC is enabled likely involves changes in the security and data access policies of the organization, and require new responsibilities, authority, and oversight within the data-centric application development community. As such, establishing and staffing the position of "database engineer" becomes even more important.
texts.text: To successfully perform monitoring, analyzing, and debugging when RCAC is enabled likely involves changes in the security and data access policies of the organization, and require new responsibilities, authority, and oversight within the data-centric application development community. As such, establishing and staffing the position of "database engineer" becomes even more important.

This information is integrated and part of the standard tools, such as Visual Explain, SQL Plan Cache Snapshot, and SQL Performance Monitor.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When implementing RCAC as part of a comprehensive and pervasive data access control initiative, consider that the database monitoring and analysis tools can collect literal values that are passed as part of SQL statements. These literal values can be viewed as part of the information collected. If any of the literals are based on or are used with masked columns, it is important to review the database engineer's policy for viewing these data elements. For example, supposed that column CUSTOMER_TAX_ID is deemed masked for the database engineer and the CUSTOMER_TAX_ID column is used in a predicate as follows:
texts.text: When implementing RCAC as part of a comprehensive and pervasive data access control initiative, consider that the database monitoring and analysis tools can collect literal values that are passed as part of SQL statements. These literal values can be viewed as part of the information collected. If any of the literals are based on or are used with masked columns, it is important to review the database engineer's policy for viewing these data elements. For example, supposed that column CUSTOMER_TAX_ID is deemed masked for the database engineer and the CUSTOMER_TAX_ID column is used in a predicate as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: WHERE CUSTOMER_TAX_ID = '123-45-7890'
texts.text: WHERE CUSTOMER_TAX_ID = '123-45-7890'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The literal value of '123-45-7890' is visible to the analyst, effectively exposing sensitive information. If this is not acceptable, you must implement the SYSPROC.SET_COLUMN_ATTRIBUTE procedure.
texts.text: The literal value of '123-45-7890' is visible to the analyst, effectively exposing sensitive information. If this is not acceptable, you must implement the SYSPROC.SET_COLUMN_ATTRIBUTE procedure.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The SET_COLUMN_ATTRIBUTE procedure sets the SECURE attribute for a column so that variable values that are used for the column cannot be seen in the SQL Performance Monitor, SQL Plan Cache Snapshot, or Visual Explain.
texts.text: The SET_COLUMN_ATTRIBUTE procedure sets the SECURE attribute for a column so that variable values that are used for the column cannot be seen in the SQL Performance Monitor, SQL Plan Cache Snapshot, or Visual Explain.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.4.2 Index advisor
texts.text: 6.4.2 Index advisor

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Because the RCAC rule text can be almost any valid SQL logic, including local selection predicates, join conditions, and subqueries, the standard query tuning techniques still apply. Without a doubt, a proper and adequate indexing strategy is a good starting point.
texts.text: Because the RCAC rule text can be almost any valid SQL logic, including local selection predicates, join conditions, and subqueries, the standard query tuning techniques still apply. Without a doubt, a proper and adequate indexing strategy is a good starting point.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The index advisor is not specifically enhanced for RCAC, but because the rule text is a fully integrated part of the query plan, any opportunities for indexing is advised based on the current Query Optimizer functionality. If an index is advised because of the RCAC rule text logic, there is no RCAC reason code provided. Analyzing the query plan and the RCAC rule text provides the understanding as to why the index is being advised.
texts.text: The index advisor is not specifically enhanced for RCAC, but because the rule text is a fully integrated part of the query plan, any opportunities for indexing is advised based on the current Query Optimizer functionality. If an index is advised because of the RCAC rule text logic, there is no RCAC reason code provided. Analyzing the query plan and the RCAC rule text provides the understanding as to why the index is being advised.

texts.orig: 6.5 Views, materialized query tables, and query rewrite with RCAC
texts.text: 6.5 Views, materialized query tables, and query rewrite with RCAC

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This section covers the implications to views, materialized query tables (MQTs), and query rewrite when RCAC is activated on a table.
texts.text: This section covers the implications to views, materialized query tables (MQTs), and query rewrite when RCAC is activated on a table.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.5.1 Views
texts.text: 6.5.1 Views

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Any access to an SQL view that is over one or more tables that have RCAC also have those row permissions and column masking rules applied. If an SQL view has predicates, those are logically ANDed with any search condition that is specified in the permissions that are defined on the underlying tables. The view does not have to project the columns that are referenced by the permissions. Figure 6-21 shows an example of a view definition and user query.
texts.text: Any access to an SQL view that is over one or more tables that have RCAC also have those row permissions and column masking rules applied. If an SQL view has predicates, those are logically ANDed with any search condition that is specified in the permissions that are defined on the underlying tables. The view does not have to project the columns that are referenced by the permissions. Figure 6-21 shows an example of a view definition and user query.

texts.orig: Figure 6-21 View definition and user query

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.5.2 Materialized query tables
texts.text: 6.5.2 Materialized query tables

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When the query to populate a materialized query table (MQT) is run by the system on either the create table or a refresh table, and one or more source tables have RCAC defined, the row permissions and column masks are ignored. This means that the MQT has all of the data.
texts.text: When the query to populate a materialized query table (MQT) is run by the system on either the create table or a refresh table, and one or more source tables have RCAC defined, the row permissions and column masks are ignored. This means that the MQT has all of the data.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Because the MQT is a copy of the base table data, when a permission is created on the base table, all the related MQTs are altered to have a default row permission. This default permission prevents any of the rows from being directly queried.
texts.text: Because the MQT is a copy of the base table data, when a permission is created on the base table, all the related MQTs are altered to have a default row permission. This default permission prevents any of the rows from being directly queried.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When a query implicitly uses an MQT, the underlying row permissions and column masks are built into the query that uses the MQT. In order for the MQT to be used for optimization, the MQT must include any columns that are used by the row permissions and column masks.
texts.text: When a query implicitly uses an MQT, the underlying row permissions and column masks are built into the query that uses the MQT. In order for the MQT to be used for optimization, the MQT must include any columns that are used by the row permissions and column masks.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The following example illustrates this scenario:
texts.text: The following example illustrates this scenario:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. Create schema and tables:
texts.text: 1. Create schema and tables:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: CREATE SCHEMA Schema1; CREATE TABLE Schema1.employee(userID varchar(128), LocationID integer, Regionid integer); CREATE TABLE Schema1.Sales (INVOICE INTEGER NOT NULL, SALEAMT DECIMAL(5,2), TAXAMT DECIMAL(5,2), LOCATIONID INTEGER, REGIONID INTEGER);
texts.text: CREATE SCHEMA Schema1; CREATE TABLE Schema1.employee(userID varchar(128), LocationID integer, Regionid integer); CREATE TABLE Schema1.Sales (INVOICE INTEGER NOT NULL, SALEAMT DECIMAL(5,2), TAXAMT DECIMAL(5,2), LOCATIONID INTEGER, REGIONID INTEGER);

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Create a row permission that allows the employees to see only rows from the region they work in:
texts.text: 2. Create a row permission that allows the employees to see only rows from the region they work in:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /* Create permission that only allows the employees to see rows from the region they work in */ CREATE PERMISSION Schema1.Sales_PERM1 ON schema1.sales FOR ROWS WHERE CURRENT_USER in (SELECT userId FROM schema1.employee E WHERE e.regionid = regionid) ENFORCED FOR ALL ACCESS ENABLE;
texts.text: /* Create permission that only allows the employees to see rows from the region they work in */ CREATE PERMISSION Schema1.Sales_PERM1 ON schema1.sales FOR ROWS WHERE CURRENT_USER in (SELECT userId FROM schema1.employee E WHERE e.regionid = regionid) ENFORCED FOR ALL ACCESS ENABLE;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. Create an MQT to summarize sales by location:
texts.text: 3. Create an MQT to summarize sales by location:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: -- Create MQT to summarize sales by location -- This has all of the data. The schema1.sales_perm1 predicate was not applied CREATE TABLE Schema1.Location_Sales_MQT as AS (SELECT LocationID, SUM(Saleamt) as Total_Location_Sales FROM SCHEMA1.SALES GROUP BY LOCATIONID) DATA INITIALLY DEFERRED REFRESH DEFERRED MAINTAINED BY USER;
texts.text: -- Create MQT to summarize sales by location -- This has all of the data. The schema1.sales_perm1 predicate was not applied CREATE TABLE Schema1.Location_Sales_MQT as AS (SELECT LocationID, SUM(Saleamt) as Total_Location_Sales FROM SCHEMA1.SALES GROUP BY LOCATIONID) DATA INITIALLY DEFERRED REFRESH DEFERRED MAINTAINED BY USER;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Populate the MQT (permission is not applied):
texts.text: 4. Populate the MQT (permission is not applied):

texts.label: text
texts.orig: /* Populate the MQT - Permission not applied here */ REFRESH TABLE Schema1.Location_Sales_MQT
texts.text: /* Populate the MQT - Permission not applied here */ REFRESH TABLE Schema1.Location_Sales_MQT

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The following query matches Location_Sales_MQT, but it cannot be used because it does not have column regionid, which is needed by the schema1.sales_PERM1 permission:
texts.text: The following query matches Location_Sales_MQT, but it cannot be used because it does not have column regionid, which is needed by the schema1.sales_PERM1 permission:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: SELECT Locationid, sum(SALEAMT) FROM schema1.sales GROUP BY locationid;
texts.text: SELECT Locationid, sum(SALEAMT) FROM schema1.sales GROUP BY locationid;

texts.text: 5. Create an MQT to summarize by region and location:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: -- MQT to summarize by region and location Create table schema1.Region_Location_Sales_MQT as AS (SELECT REGIONID, LocationID, SUM(Saleamt) as Total_Location_Sales FROM SCHEMA1.SALES GROUP BY REGIONID, LOCATIONID) DATA INITIALLY DEFERRED REFRESH DEFERRED MAINTAINED BY USER;
texts.text: -- MQT to summarize by region and location Create table schema1.Region_Location_Sales_MQT as AS (SELECT REGIONID, LocationID, SUM(Saleamt) as Total_Location_Sales FROM SCHEMA1.SALES GROUP BY REGIONID, LOCATIONID) DATA INITIALLY DEFERRED REFRESH DEFERRED MAINTAINED BY USER;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 6. Populate the Region_location_Sales_MQT (permission not applied):
texts.text: 6. Populate the Region_location_Sales_MQT (permission not applied):

texts.label: text
texts.orig: /* Populate the Region_location_Sales_MQT - Permission not applied here */ Refresh table schema1.Region_Location_Sales_MQT
texts.text: /* Populate the Region_location_Sales_MQT - Permission not applied here */ Refresh table schema1.Region_Location_Sales_MQT

texts.text: The following query can use the Region_location_SALES_MQT because it has REGIONID, which is required for the schema1.sales_PERM1 permission:

texts.text: SELECT Locationid, sum(SALEAMT) FROM schema1.sales GROUP BY locationid;

texts.orig: This example has the following additional implications:
texts.text: This example has the following additional implications:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Users must be prevented from explicitly querying the MQT or a view that is created over it. Those two cases bypass the row permission and column mask rules from the underlying tables.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Users must be prevented from explicitly querying the MQT or a view that is created over it. Those two cases bypass the row permission and column mask rules from the underlying tables.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> If the user writes code to update incrementally an MQT, that code must be run from a user that has permission to view all of the rows and all columns in their unmasked state. Otherwise, the MQT contents are not complete and queries that implicitly use the MQT might get wrong results.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> If the user writes code to update incrementally an MQT, that code must be run from a user that has permission to view all of the rows and all columns in their unmasked state. Otherwise, the MQT contents are not complete and queries that implicitly use the MQT might get wrong results.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> To prevent this, a check constraint can be created to cause an error if masked data was inserted into the MQT.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> To prevent this, a check constraint can be created to cause an error if masked data was inserted into the MQT.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.5.3 Query rewrite
texts.text: 6.5.3 Query rewrite

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Query rewrite is a technique that the optimizer can use to change the original request to improve performance.
texts.text: Query rewrite is a technique that the optimizer can use to change the original request to improve performance.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For example, a query that references Table1 might be rewritten to access an MQT over Table1, or it might also be optimized to access only the fields in an index that is defined over Table1 and avoid touching Table1. With RCAC, defining these rewrites can still occur, but the MQT or index also must include all columns that are needed by the row permissions or column masks that are defined on Table1.
texts.text: For example, a query that references Table1 might be rewritten to access an MQT over Table1, or it might also be optimized to access only the fields in an index that is defined over Table1 and avoid touching Table1. With RCAC, defining these rewrites can still occur, but the MQT or index also must include all columns that are needed by the row permissions or column masks that are defined on Table1.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As part of adding RCAC, the impact to these potentially significant performance optimizations must be considered. Usage of MQTs or index-only access might be reduced or eliminated by enabling RCAC.
texts.text: As part of adding RCAC, the impact to these potentially significant performance optimizations must be considered. Usage of MQTs or index-only access might be reduced or eliminated by enabling RCAC.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.6 RCAC effects on performance and scalability
texts.text: 6.6 RCAC effects on performance and scalability

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As with any discussion that is related to performance and scalability, nothing is certain or guaranteed. There are always many variables that are involved. First, a good foundation of knowledge and skill is required to appreciate fully what is occurring when a database request is handled within an RCAC enabled environment. Implementing the row permission or column masks involves the query optimizer and database engine. The process that identifies the rows that you have permission to access is considered a "query", and as such a query plan must be formulated. In the case of SQL requests, the RCAC portion of the query is combined with the user's query, much like a query referencing a view.
texts.text: As with any discussion that is related to performance and scalability, nothing is certain or guaranteed. There are always many variables that are involved. First, a good foundation of knowledge and skill is required to appreciate fully what is occurring when a database request is handled within an RCAC enabled environment. Implementing the row permission or column masks involves the query optimizer and database engine. The process that identifies the rows that you have permission to access is considered a "query", and as such a query plan must be formulated. In the case of SQL requests, the RCAC portion of the query is combined with the user's query, much like a query referencing a view.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For native record level access, this RCAC "query" is also built and used to test the permission. When a file is opened, the RCAC rule text logic is included, optimized, and run as part of the native read, write, update, or delete operation. The amount of work (and time) required to identify the record based on the user's permission is directly related to the complexity and depth of the logic that is needed to identify the records that can be returned.
texts.text: For native record level access, this RCAC "query" is also built and used to test the permission. When a file is opened, the RCAC rule text logic is included, optimized, and run as part of the native read, write, update, or delete operation. The amount of work (and time) required to identify the record based on the user's permission is directly related to the complexity and depth of the logic that is needed to identify the records that can be returned.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A simple example to illustrate this concept is a random read using a keyed logical file (that is, an index). In its purest form, a random read uses two data access methods: index probe (find the key and RRN) and table probe (find the record using RRN). If the RCAC rule text specifies five nested subqueries to determine whether the user has access to the record, this logic must be added to the path. The subquery processing now becomes part of the original "random read" request. Instead of two simple I/Os to retrieve the record, there can be a minimum of 12 I/Os to retrieve the same record. These I/Os can be done with a result of "not found" if the user is not entitled to any of the records.
texts.text: A simple example to illustrate this concept is a random read using a keyed logical file (that is, an index). In its purest form, a random read uses two data access methods: index probe (find the key and RRN) and table probe (find the record using RRN). If the RCAC rule text specifies five nested subqueries to determine whether the user has access to the record, this logic must be added to the path. The subquery processing now becomes part of the original "random read" request. Instead of two simple I/Os to retrieve the record, there can be a minimum of 12 I/Os to retrieve the same record. These I/Os can be done with a result of "not found" if the user is not entitled to any of the records.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For programs that access records sequentially, in or out of key order, the added RCAC logic can have a profound effect on the performance and scalability. Reading the "next record" in order is no longer a simple matter of positioning to the next available key, as shown in Figure 6-23.
texts.text: For programs that access records sequentially, in or out of key order, the added RCAC logic can have a profound effect on the performance and scalability. Reading the "next record" in order is no longer a simple matter of positioning to the next available key, as shown in Figure 6-23.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-23 Native record access with no RCAC
texts.text: Figure 6-23 Native record access with no RCAC

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Before the record, as identified by the key, is considered available, the RCAC logic must be run. If the record is rejected by RCAC, the next record in sequence that is permissible must be identified. This spinning through the records can take a long time and uses many resources, as shown in Figure 6-24.
texts.text: Before the record, as identified by the key, is considered available, the RCAC logic must be run. If the record is rejected by RCAC, the next record in sequence that is permissible must be identified. This spinning through the records can take a long time and uses many resources, as shown in Figure 6-24.

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Figure 6-24 Native record level access with RCAC
texts.text: Figure 6-24 Native record level access with RCAC

texts.label: text
texts.orig: After the row permissions and column masks are designed and implemented, adequate performance and scalability testing are recommended.
texts.text: After the row permissions and column masks are designed and implemented, adequate performance and scalability testing are recommended.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.7 Exclusive lock to implement RCAC (availability issues)
texts.text: 6.7 Exclusive lock to implement RCAC (availability issues)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When defining permissions or enabling RCAC, an exclusive lock on the base table is obtained. The impact to other applications depends on the order of create permission and the alter table to activate RCAC.
texts.text: When defining permissions or enabling RCAC, an exclusive lock on the base table is obtained. The impact to other applications depends on the order of create permission and the alter table to activate RCAC.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Consider the following scenarios:
texts.text: Consider the following scenarios:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Scenario 1: Adding permissions and RCAC is not enabled on the table:
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Scenario 1: Adding permissions and RCAC is not enabled on the table:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: -Job 1 reading data from the table (open for input) holds a *SHRRD on the member and a *SHRRD on the data.
texts.text: -Job 1 reading data from the table (open for input) holds a *SHRRD on the member and a *SHRRD on the data.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: -Job 2 adding, updating, or deleting rows from table (open for output) holds a *SHRRD on the member and a *SHRUPD on the data.
texts.text: -Job 2 adding, updating, or deleting rows from table (open for output) holds a *SHRRD on the member and a *SHRUPD on the data.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: -Job 4 allocates the object and gets a *SHRRD on the file and a *EXCLRD on the data.
texts.text: -Job 4 allocates the object and gets a *SHRRD on the file and a *EXCLRD on the data.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: -Job 3 attempts to add a permission to the table. Permission is added and the pseudo-closed cursors for Job1 and Job 2 are closed. Job 4 still holds the *SHRRD on the file and *EXCLRD on the data.
texts.text: -Job 3 attempts to add a permission to the table. Permission is added and the pseudo-closed cursors for Job1 and Job 2 are closed. Job 4 still holds the *SHRRD on the file and *EXCLRD on the data.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The net result from Scenario 1 is that you can add permissions without having to end the applications that are reading the base table.
texts.text: The net result from Scenario 1 is that you can add permissions without having to end the applications that are reading the base table.

texts.label: page_footer
texts.orig: Chapter 6. Additional considerations
texts.text: Chapter 6. Additional considerations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Scenario 2: Altering a table to activate RCAC requires that all applications using the table be ended. The alter table requires exclusive use of the table.
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Scenario 2: Altering a table to activate RCAC requires that all applications using the table be ended. The alter table requires exclusive use of the table.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: GLYPH<SM590000> Scenario 3: Altering the table to activate RCAC before the permissions are added. The alter table requires exclusive use of the table, as in scenario 2. All applications must be ended to perform this alter. After the alter is complete, any applications trying to read data do not get any results, and attempts to insert new rows returns the following message:
texts.text: GLYPH<SM590000> Scenario 3: Altering the table to activate RCAC before the permissions are added. The alter table requires exclusive use of the table, as in scenario 2. All applications must be ended to perform this alter. After the alter is complete, any applications trying to read data do not get any results, and attempts to insert new rows returns the following message:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: SQ20471] INSERT or UPDATE does not satisfy row permissions.
texts.text: SQ20471] INSERT or UPDATE does not satisfy row permissions.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: To create a permission in this case requires that you end all the applications, unlike scenario 1 where permissions can be added while the applications were active. In this case, the applications must be ended to run the create permission.
texts.text: To create a permission in this case requires that you end all the applications, unlike scenario 1 where permissions can be added while the applications were active. In this case, the applications must be ended to run the create permission.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.8 Avoiding propagation of masked data
texts.text: 6.8 Avoiding propagation of masked data

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Operations such as insert or update into a table with active column access control can fail if the input data is masked data. This can happen when data to be inserted or updated contains the masked value as a result of a SELECT from a table with active column access control.
texts.text: Operations such as insert or update into a table with active column access control can fail if the input data is masked data. This can happen when data to be inserted or updated contains the masked value as a result of a SELECT from a table with active column access control.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For example, assume TABLE1 and TABLE2 have active column access control and for insert, selecting data from TABLE2 returns the masked data. The following INSERT returns an error:
texts.text: For example, assume TABLE1 and TABLE2 have active column access control and for insert, selecting data from TABLE2 returns the masked data. The following INSERT returns an error:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: INSERT INTO TABLE1 SELECT * FROM TABLE2
texts.text: INSERT INTO TABLE1 SELECT * FROM TABLE2

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The masked data that is returned from the SELECT * FROM TABLE2 might not be valid input data for TABLE1 because of data type or column check constraint.
texts.text: The masked data that is returned from the SELECT * FROM TABLE2 might not be valid input data for TABLE1 because of data type or column check constraint.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There are two ways to prevent this situation from happening: Define a check constraint or create a before trigger.
texts.text: There are two ways to prevent this situation from happening: Define a check constraint or create a before trigger.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.8.1 Check constraint solution
texts.text: 6.8.1 Check constraint solution

texts.label: text
texts.orig: One way to prevent this problem is to define a check constraint.
texts.text: One way to prevent this problem is to define a check constraint.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As part of RCAC, new SQL syntax is provided to allow an action to be performed when a violation of the check constraints check condition occurs instead of giving that error. However, if the check condition is still not met after the action, a hard error is returned. A check constraint with the new on-violation-clause is allowed on both the CREATE TABLE and ALTER TABLE statements.
texts.text: As part of RCAC, new SQL syntax is provided to allow an action to be performed when a violation of the check constraints check condition occurs instead of giving that error. However, if the check condition is still not met after the action, a hard error is returned. A check constraint with the new on-violation-clause is allowed on both the CREATE TABLE and ALTER TABLE statements.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In the Example 6-4, the mask is defined to return a value of 'XXX-XX-nnnn' for any query that is not done by a user profile in the DBMGR group. The constraint checks that the column SSN does not have the masked value.
texts.text: In the Example 6-4, the mask is defined to return a value of 'XXX-XX-nnnn' for any query that is not done by a user profile in the DBMGR group. The constraint checks that the column SSN does not have the masked value.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Example 6-4 Check constraint to avoid masked data
texts.text: Example 6-4 Check constraint to avoid masked data

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CREATE SCHEMA MY_LIB SET SCHEMA MY_LIB CREATE TABLE MY_LIB.EMP_INFO (COL1_name CHAR(10) WITH DEFAULT 'DEFAULT', COL2_ssn CHAR(11) WITH DEFAULT 'DEFAULT') CREATE MASK MASK_ssn ON MY_LIB.EMP_INFO FOR COLUMN COL2_ssn RETURN CASE WHEN VERIFY_GROUP_FOR_USER ( SESSION_USER , 'DBMGR' ) = 1 THEN COL2_ssn
texts.text: CREATE SCHEMA MY_LIB SET SCHEMA MY_LIB CREATE TABLE MY_LIB.EMP_INFO (COL1_name CHAR(10) WITH DEFAULT 'DEFAULT', COL2_ssn CHAR(11) WITH DEFAULT 'DEFAULT') CREATE MASK MASK_ssn ON MY_LIB.EMP_INFO FOR COLUMN COL2_ssn RETURN CASE WHEN VERIFY_GROUP_FOR_USER ( SESSION_USER , 'DBMGR' ) = 1 THEN COL2_ssn

texts.label: page_footer
texts.orig: Row and Column Access Control Support in IBM DB2 for i
texts.text: Row and Column Access Control Support in IBM DB2 for i

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ELSE 'XXX-XX-'||SUBSTR(COL2_ssn,8,4) END ENABLE | /* Check constraint for the update and insert.*/ ALTER TABLE MY_LIB.EMP_INFO ADD CONSTRAINT MASK_ssn_preserve CHECK(SUBSTR(COL2_ssn,1,7)<>'XXX-XX-') -- Allow any value other than the mask ON UPDATE VIOLATION PRESERVE COL2_ssn -- Don't update the mask portion of the existing value ON INSERT VIOLATION SET COL2_ssn = DEFAULT -- for insert set this to the default value.
texts.text: ELSE 'XXX-XX-'||SUBSTR(COL2_ssn,8,4) END ENABLE | /* Check constraint for the update and insert.*/ ALTER TABLE MY_LIB.EMP_INFO ADD CONSTRAINT MASK_ssn_preserve CHECK(SUBSTR(COL2_ssn,1,7)<>'XXX-XX-') -- Allow any value other than the mask ON UPDATE VIOLATION PRESERVE COL2_ssn -- Don't update the mask portion of the existing value ON INSERT VIOLATION SET COL2_ssn = DEFAULT -- for insert set this to the default value.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.8.2 Before trigger solution
texts.text: 6.8.2 Before trigger solution

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The actions that are described in Example 6-4 on page 108 for ON UPDATE VIOLATION and ON INSERT VIOLATION also can be handled by a before trigger, as shown in Example 6-5.
texts.text: The actions that are described in Example 6-4 on page 108 for ON UPDATE VIOLATION and ON INSERT VIOLATION also can be handled by a before trigger, as shown in Example 6-5.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Example 6-5 Before trigger to avoid masked data
texts.text: Example 6-5 Before trigger to avoid masked data

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CREATE TRIGGER PREVENT_MASK_SSN BEFORE INSERT OR UPDATE ON MY_LIB.EMP_INFO REFERENCING NEW ROW AS N OLD ROW AS O FOR EACH ROW MODE DB2ROW SECURED WHEN(SUBSTR(N.COL2_ssn,1,7) = 'XXX-XX-') BEGIN IF INSERTING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = DEFAULT; ELSEIF UPDATING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = O.COL2_ssn; END IF; END
texts.text: CREATE TRIGGER PREVENT_MASK_SSN BEFORE INSERT OR UPDATE ON MY_LIB.EMP_INFO REFERENCING NEW ROW AS N OLD ROW AS O FOR EACH ROW MODE DB2ROW SECURED WHEN(SUBSTR(N.COL2_ssn,1,7) = 'XXX-XX-') BEGIN IF INSERTING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = DEFAULT; ELSEIF UPDATING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = O.COL2_ssn; END IF; END

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.9 Triggers and functions (SECURED)
texts.text: 6.9 Triggers and functions (SECURED)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There are some considerations that must be considered when there are triggers and functions on tables that have RCAC enabled. The purpose of SECURE for triggers and functions is so that a user who is allowed to create a trigger or function is not necessarily able to make it SECURE themselves. This prevents the trigger/function developer from adding code that skims off data that they are not allowed to see.
texts.text: There are some considerations that must be considered when there are triggers and functions on tables that have RCAC enabled. The purpose of SECURE for triggers and functions is so that a user who is allowed to create a trigger or function is not necessarily able to make it SECURE themselves. This prevents the trigger/function developer from adding code that skims off data that they are not allowed to see.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.9.1 Triggers
texts.text: 6.9.1 Triggers

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Triggers have access to the data in rows outside of the row permission or column masking. An after trigger has access to the new row image after the permission has allowed the update or insert to occur. Therefore, the triggers can potentially change the insert or update image value so that it violates the permission.
texts.text: Triggers have access to the data in rows outside of the row permission or column masking. An after trigger has access to the new row image after the permission has allowed the update or insert to occur. Therefore, the triggers can potentially change the insert or update image value so that it violates the permission.

texts.label: page_footer
texts.orig: Chapter 6. Additional considerations
texts.text: Chapter 6. Additional considerations

texts.label: page_footer
texts.orig: Row and Column Access Control Support in IBM DB2 for i
texts.text: Row and Column Access Control Support in IBM DB2 for i

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Any triggers that are defined on a table must be created with an attribute that designates that it is SECURED when RCAC definitions are created or altered for that table, as shown in Example 6-6. The same applies to a view that has an instead of trigger. That trigger must be secure at the point RCAC is enabled for any of the underlying tables the view is over.
texts.text: Any triggers that are defined on a table must be created with an attribute that designates that it is SECURED when RCAC definitions are created or altered for that table, as shown in Example 6-6. The same applies to a view that has an instead of trigger. That trigger must be secure at the point RCAC is enabled for any of the underlying tables the view is over.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Example 6-6 Trigger SECURED
texts.text: Example 6-6 Trigger SECURED

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /* Trigger created with the SECURED attribute */ CREATE TRIGGER PREVENT_MASK_SSN BEFORE INSERT OR UPDATE ON MY_LIB.EMP_INFO REFERENCING NEW ROW AS N OLD ROW AS O FOR EACH ROW MODE DB2ROW SECURED WHEN(SUBSTR(N.COL2_ssn,1,7) = 'XXX-XX-') BEGIN IF INSERTING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = DEFAULT; ELSEIF UPDATING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = O.COL2_ssn; END IF; END
texts.text: /* Trigger created with the SECURED attribute */ CREATE TRIGGER PREVENT_MASK_SSN BEFORE INSERT OR UPDATE ON MY_LIB.EMP_INFO REFERENCING NEW ROW AS N OLD ROW AS O FOR EACH ROW MODE DB2ROW SECURED WHEN(SUBSTR(N.COL2_ssn,1,7) = 'XXX-XX-') BEGIN IF INSERTING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = DEFAULT; ELSEIF UPDATING THEN SET N.COL2_ssn = O.COL2_ssn; END IF; END

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6.9.2 Functions
texts.text: 6.9.2 Functions

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Within a CREATE PERMISSION or CREATE MASK , a function can be called. Because that UDF has access to the data before the RCAC rules are applied, the SECURE attribute is required on that function, as shown in Example 6-7.
texts.text: Within a CREATE PERMISSION or CREATE MASK , a function can be called. Because that UDF has access to the data before the RCAC rules are applied, the SECURE attribute is required on that function, as shown in Example 6-7.

texts.label: code
texts.orig: Example 6-7 Specifying SECURED on a function CREATE PERMISSION SCHEMA.PERM1 ON SCHEMA.TABLE1 FOR ROWS WHERE MY_UDF(CURRENT_USER,COLUMN1) = 1 ENFORCED FOR ALL ACCESS ENABLE; CREATE FUNCTION MY_UDF (INP1 CHAR(32), INP2 INTEGER) Returns INTEGER LANGUAGE SQL CONTAINS SQL SECURED
texts.text: Example 6-7 Specifying SECURED on a function CREATE PERMISSION SCHEMA.PERM1 ON SCHEMA.TABLE1 FOR ROWS WHERE MY_UDF(CURRENT_USER,COLUMN1) = 1 ENFORCED FOR ALL ACCESS ENABLE; CREATE FUNCTION MY_UDF (INP1 CHAR(32), INP2 INTEGER) Returns INTEGER LANGUAGE SQL CONTAINS SQL SECURED

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The SECURED attribute of MY_UDF signifies that the function is considered secure for RCAC. If a function is called from an SQL statement, and references a column in a table that has RCAC, it must be declared as secure. In that case, if the secure function calls other functions, they are not validated to confirm whether they are secure.
texts.text: The SECURED attribute of MY_UDF signifies that the function is considered secure for RCAC. If a function is called from an SQL statement, and references a column in a table that has RCAC, it must be declared as secure. In that case, if the secure function calls other functions, they are not validated to confirm whether they are secure.
